52824fe6e4b08f1425d6e23c|5488c095e4b02acb4f0c92d2.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/onlink|http://water.usgs.gov/lookup/getspatial?ds866_ssurgo_variables
52824fe6e4b08f1425d6e23c|5488c095e4b02acb4f0c92d2.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/abstract|This digital data release consists of seven data files of soil attributes for the United States and the District of Columbia. The files are derived from Natural Resources Conservations Services (NRCS) Soil Survey Geographic database (SSURGO). The data files can be linked to the raster datasets of soil mapping unit identifiers (MUKEY) available through the NRCSs Gridded Soil Survey Geographic (gSSURGO) database (http://www.nrcs.usda.gov/wps/portal/nrcs/detail/soils/survey/geo/?cid=nrcs142p2_053628). The associated files, named DRAINAGECLASS, HYDRATING, HYDGRP, HYDRICCONDITION, LAYER, TEXT, and WTDEP are area- and depth-weighted average values for selected soil characteristics from the SSURGO database for the conterminous United States and the District of Columbia. The SSURGO tables were acquired from the NRCS on March 5, 2014. The soil characteristics in the DRAINAGE table are drainage class (DRNCLASS), which identifies the natural drainage conditions of the soil and refers to the frequency and duration of wet periods. The soil characteristics in the HYDRATING table are hydric rating (HYDRATE), a yes/no field that indicates whether or not a map unit component is classified as a "hydric soil". The soil characteristics in the HYDGRP table are the percentages for each hydrologic group per MUKEY. The soil characteristics in the HYDRICCONDITION table are hydric condition (HYDCON), which describes the natural condition of the soil component. The soil characteristics in the LAYER table are available water capacity (AVG_AWC), bulk density (AVG_BD), saturated hydraulic conductivity (AVG_KSAT), vertical saturated hydraulic conductivity (AVG_KV), soil erodibility factor (AVG_KFACT), porosity (AVG_POR), field capacity (AVG_FC), the soil fraction passing a number 4 sieve (AVG_NO4), the soil fraction passing a number 10 sieve (AVG_NO10), the soil fraction passing a number 200 sieve (AVG_NO200), and organic matter (AVG_OM). The soil characteristics in the TEXT table are percent sand, silt, and clay (AVG_SAND, AVG_SILT, and AVG_CLAY). The soil characteristics in the WTDEP table are the annual minimum water table depth (WTDEP_MIN), available water storage in the 0-25 cm soil horizon (AWS025), the minimum water table depth for the months April, May and June (WTDEPAMJ), the available water storage in the first 25 centimeters of the soil horizon (AWS25), the dominant drainage class (DRCLSD), the wettest drainage class (DRCLSWET), and the hydric classification (HYDCLASS), which is an indication of the proportion of the map unit, expressed as a class, that is "hydric", based on the hydric classification of a given MUKEY. (See Entity_Description for more detail). The tables were created with a set of arc macro language (aml) and awk (awk was created at Bell Labsin the 1970s and its name is derived from the first letters of the last namesof its authors  Alfred Aho, Peter Weinberger, and Brian Kernighan) scripts. Send an email to mewieczo@usgs.gov to obtain copies of the computer code (See Process_Description.) The methods used are outlined in NRCS's "SSURGO Data Packaging and Use" (NRCS, 2011). The tables can be related or joined to the gSSURGO rasters of MUKEYs by the item 'MUKEY.' Joining or relating the tables to a MUKEY grid allows the creation of grids of area- and depth-weighted soil characteristics. A 90-meter raster of MUKEYs is provided which can be used to produce rasters of soil attributes. More detailed resolution rasters are available through NRCS via the link above.
52824fe6e4b08f1425d6e23c|5488c095e4b02acb4f0c92d2.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/purpose|The data were derived for use in studies requiring estimates of soil characteristics. The georeferenced soil characteristics were intended to be averaged over large areas, such as over a river basin, and used for (1) watershed simulation models that require spatially lumped estimates of soil hydraulic parameters, and (2) as explanatory variables in regional and national water-quality assessment studies.

52824fe6e4b08f1425d6e23c|5488c095e4b02acb4f0c92d2.xml|/metadata/idinfo/useconst|The U.S. Department of Agriculture, Natural Resources Conservation Service (NRCS, 2014), should be acknowledged as the data source in products derived from these data. This data is an interpretation of the SSURGO source data and users are cautioned to read all the meatdata and use it accordingly. This dataset is not designed for use as a primary regulatory tool in permitting or siting decisions, but may be used as a reference source. This is public information and may be interpreted by organizations, agencies, units of government, or others based on needs; however, they are responsible for the appropriate application. Federal, State, or local regulatory bodies are not to reassign to the Natural Resources Conservation Service any authority for the decisions that they make. The Natural Resources Conservation Service will not perform any evaluations of these maps for purposes related solely to State or local regulatory programs.Photographic or digital enlargement of these maps to scales greater than those at which they were originally mapped can cause misinterpretation of the data. If enlarged, maps do not show the small areas of contrasting soils that could have been shown at a larger scale. The depicted soil boundaries, interpretations, and analysis derived from them do not eliminate the need for onsite sampling, testing, and detailed study of specific sites for intensive uses. Thus, these data and their interpretations are intended for planning purposes only. Digital data files are periodically updated. Files are dated, and users are responsible for obtaining the latest version of the data.

52824fe6e4b08f1425d6e23c|5488c095e4b02acb4f0c92d2.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/srcinfo/srccite/citeinfo/onlink|http://websoilsurvey.nrcs.usda.gov/

52824fe6e4b08f1425d6e23c|5488c095e4b02acb4f0c92d2.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/srcinfo/srctime/timeinfo/sngdate/caldate|2014

52824fe6e4b08f1425d6e23c|5488c095e4b02acb4f0c92d2.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/srcinfo/srccitea|Soil Survey Geographic (SSURGO) Database
52824fe6e4b08f1425d6e23c|5488c095e4b02acb4f0c92d2.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/srcinfo/srccontr|The SSURGO database contains information about soil as collected by the National Cooperative Soil Survey over the course of a century. The information can be displayed in tables or as maps and is available for most areas in the United States and the Territories, Commonwealths, and Island Nations served by the USDA-NRCS. The information was gathered by walking over the land and observing the soil. Many soil samples were analyzed in laboratories. The maps outline areas called map units. The map units describe soils and other components that have unique properties, interpretations, and productivity. The information was collected at scales ranging from 1:12,000 to 1:63,360. More details were gathered at a scale of 1:12,000 than at a scale of 1:63,360. The mapping is intended for natural resource planning and management by landowners, townships, and counties. Some knowledge of soils data and map scale is necessary to avoid misunderstandings. The maps are linked in the database to information about the component soils and their properties for each map unit. Each map unit may contain one to three major components and some minor components. The map units are typically named for the major components. Examples of information available from the database include available water capacity, soil reaction, electrical conductivity, and frequency of flooding; yields for cropland, woodland, rangeland, and pastureland; and limitations affecting recreational development, building site development, and other engineering uses. SSURGO datasets consist of map data, tabular data, and information about how the maps and tables were created. The extent of a SSURGO dataset is a soil survey area, which may consist of a single county, multiple counties, or parts of multiple counties. SSURGO map data can be viewed in the Web Soil Survey or downloaded in ESRI Shapefile format. The coordinate systems are Geographic. Attribute data can be downloaded in text format that can be imported into a Microsoft Access database.
52824fe6e4b08f1425d6e23c|5488c095e4b02acb4f0c92d2.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|In order to process soil attributes by soil mapping unit (MUKEY) from the SSURGO database, at least three tables (mapunit, component, and CHORIZON) are needed along with the spatial coverages. These files can be accessed from NRCS (http://www.nrcs.usda.gov/wps/portal/nrcs/detail/soils/survey/geo/?cid=nrcs142p2_053628). All available data were downloaded, processed as outlined below. SSURGO map unit data are stored in the map unit table (MAPUNIT.TXT), and are referenced by the field MUKEY. Map units consist of multiple, unmapped soil types called "components." Component data are stored in the component table (COMP.TXT), and are referenced by the field COKEY. Soil components (or soil type) are associated with multiple horizons. Horizon data are stored in the CHORIZON table (CHORIZON.TXT), and are referenced by the field COKEY. Since there is a one to many (mapunit:component:horizon) relationship between spatial and horizon-level soil property data, two aggregation steps are required in order to produce a thematic map. Deriving MUKEY average values for permeability, available water capacity, bulk density, saturated hydraulic conductivity, soil erodibility, field capacity, porosity, average soil thickness, and organic matter required that a weighted-average value be computed for all the soil horizons in a soil component, and then a weighted-average value was computed for all the soil components in a soil mapping unit. First, the component average values were computed by weighting the layer values by their thickness. Second, the MUKEY average was computed by weighting the component average values by their percentage composition of the MUKEY. Each step of the two-step weighting process was done exactly as described above: first, the layer values were weighted by their thicknesses and then the component values were weighted by their percentage composition. The methods used to derive soil variables were taken from the NRCS's SSURGO Data Packaging and Use (NRCS, 2011, http://www.nrcs.usda.gov/wps/portal/nrcs/detail/soils/ref/?cid=nrcs142p2_053631). ESRI's ArcInfo Workstation version 9.2 and GNU's awk program version 1.2.0 were used to process all SSURGO files. A weighted average of the soil property value for all components in the map unit is used to attribute the map unit for that soil property. Percent composition is used as the weighting factor. This aggregation method is only suitable for numerical attributes. If the soil property being aggregated is an attribute of a soil horizon, then a single value for all included horizons must be determined for each component before computing a weighted average for all components. In this case, the single component value is also computed as a weighted average, where the weighting factor for each horizon is its percentage of the depth range in question. In the following example, a weighted-average value for total clay is calculated. Step 1. For each component, a weighted-average value for clay is calculated. Clay = SUM (horizon thickness/total thickness X total clay) for all included soil horizons. Table: component: MUKEY (Mapping Unit) COKEY (component key) Percent of Component* 100017 100017:149541 60 100017 100017:149542 40 Table: CHORIZON COKEY (component key) Horizon Depth Clay 100017:149541 20 9.5 100017:149541 56 12.5 100017:149541 76 1.5 100017:149542 20 9.5 100017:149542 10 11.5 100017:149542 122 3.5 100017:149541 [ ( ( 20/152) *9.5 ) + ( ( 56/152 ) * 12.5 ) + ( ( 76/152 ) * 1.5 ) ] = 6.60 100017:149542 [ ( ( 20/152) *9.5 ) + ( ( 10/152 ) * 11.5 ) + ( ( 122/152 ) * 3.5 ) ]= 4.82 Step 2. For each map unit, a weighted-average value for total clay in the upper 50 centimeters (cm) or less of the soil is calculated. Total Clay in the Upper 50 cm (or less) = SUM (percent composition* Total Clay in the Upper 50 cm (or less) for all components in the map unit mukey Total Clay in the Upper 50 cm (or less) 100017:149541 .60 * 6.60 = 3.96 100017:149542 .40 * 4.82 = 1.93 10017 = 3.96 + 1.93 = 5.89 * SSURGO is often an incomplete database and at times, the component percentages do not add up to 100 for a MUKEY. When components do not add up to 100, the following calculation is used to ensure that the components are treated as 100% Table: component: MUKEY (Mapping Unit) COKEY (component key) Percent of Component 100017 100017:149541 60 100017 100017:149542 30 100017:149541 60 / (60 + 30 ) = 66.66 Percent of Component 100017:149542 30 / (60 + 30 ) = 33.33 Percent of Component MUKEYs where components did not add up to 100% were flagged accoding to the following criteria (NRCS, written communic. 3/2014): 95 - 105 data were deemed reliable. Less than 95 data were deemed unreliable. Greater than 105 data were deemed suspect. Each soil attribute in this table was processed this way except for vertical saturated hydraulic conductivity (KV) and porosity (POR). Saturated hydraulic conductivity (KV) was calculated the following way: KV = d / sum ( di / Ki ) where KV is the vertical conductivity; d is the total soil thickness = sum (di); di is the thickness of layer i; and Ki is the permeability of layer i (found in the SSURGO table CHORIZON; KSAT_R which is the saturated hydraulic conductivity). Porosity (POR) was calculated the following way: POR = 1 - [( bulk density) / (particle density)] where bulk density is the item wthirdbar_r found in the SSURGO table CHORIZON. particledensity is the item partdensity found in the SSURGO table CHORIZON.

52824fe6e4b08f1425d6e23c|5488c096e4b02acb4f0c92da.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/lworkcit/citeinfo/title|Maps and Geospatial Data for the Shorty's Island and Myrtle Bend Substrate Enhancement Pilot Projects, Kootenai River Near Bonners Ferry, Idaho
52824fe6e4b08f1425d6e23c|5488c096e4b02acb4f0c92da.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/lworkcit/citeinfo/serinfo/sername|U.S. Geological Survey Data Series
52824fe6e4b08f1425d6e23c|5488c096e4b02acb4f0c92da.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/lworkcit/citeinfo/serinfo/issue|889, 9 p
52824fe6e4b08f1425d6e23c|5488c096e4b02acb4f0c92da.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/lworkcit/citeinfo/onlink|http://dx.doi.org/10.3133/ds889
52824fe6e4b08f1425d6e23c|5488c096e4b02acb4f0c92da.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/abstract|The egg-mat data describe a sub-set of the egg-mat network operated by the Idaho Department of Fish and Game. The sub-set inlcudes two sites, 1. near an area commonly known as Shorty's Island, and 2. near the Kootenai River confluence with Myrtle Creek at an area commonly known as Myrtle Bend. The egg-mats consist of artificial substrate mats that are deployed and retrieved every 24-48 hours by IDFG personnel. The egg-mat material is designed to trap eggs that come in contact with the mat, allow personnel to quanitify the number of eggs for the deployed period. The egg-mat data is described by date, quantity of eggs retrieved, and the spatial location (geographic and projected coordinates).
52824fe6e4b08f1425d6e23c|5488c096e4b02acb4f0c92da.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/purpose|These data are intended to be combined with bathymetric, surficial sediment facies, and streamflow characteristics to describe the physical habitat occupied by Kootenai River white sturgeon during spawning and early-life phases. These data can be used with geographic information systems (GIS) or other software to display the Kootenai River White Sturgeon Egg-Mat Network near Shorty's Island and Myrtle Bend operated by the Idaho Department of Fish and Game.

52824fe6e4b08f1425d6e23c|5488c096e4b02acb4f0c92da.xml|/metadata/dataqual/attracc/attraccr|The Date and number of eggs are believed to be accurately reported.
52824fe6e4b08f1425d6e23c|5488c096e4b02acb4f0c92da.xml|/metadata/dataqual/logic|No checks were made to ensure the correct dates and number of eggs were recorded.
52824fe6e4b08f1425d6e23c|5488c096e4b02acb4f0c92da.xml|/metadata/dataqual/complete|For datasets including 2007 and 2009 - 2013, GPS positions were recorded for all egg-mats. In 2008, GPS position data was not recoreded for egg mats with zero-eggs recovered.
52824fe6e4b08f1425d6e23c|5488c096e4b02acb4f0c92da.xml|/metadata/dataqual/posacc/horizpa/horizpar|The positional accuracy of the egg-mat data was not verified. Numerous points were deleted that did not fall within the extent of the riverine area. These data are believed to have been recorded erroneously, either by human error or positioning error from the GPS. The average horizontal uncertainty of the egg-mats, based on positional uncertainties of hand-held mapping grade GPS units, is around 3-10 meters. Additional positional uncertainty, such as movement caused by drifting in the current, is unknown but thought to be within the error of the GPS (3-10 meters).
52824fe6e4b08f1425d6e23c|5488c096e4b02acb4f0c92da.xml|/metadata/dataqual/posacc/vertacc/vertaccr|Not applicable to this dataset.
52824fe6e4b08f1425d6e23c|5488c096e4b02acb4f0c92da.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|Idaho Fish and Game personnel deployed and retrieved the egg-mats on a 24 to 48 hour rotation during the spawning season. The egg-mat spatial locations were recorded using a mapping grade GPS unit, and the date and time were recorded for both the deployment and retrieval. If eggs were recovered after the egg-mat was retrieved, the number of eggs was recorded and the eggs were placed in vials.
52824fe6e4b08f1425d6e23c|5488c096e4b02acb4f0c92da.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdate|unknown
52824fe6e4b08f1425d6e23c|5488c096e4b02acb4f0c92da.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|Idaho Fish and Game personnel entered the spatial location, date, time, number of eggs and other ancillary data was entered into a spreadsheet for each year (2007 - 2013).
52824fe6e4b08f1425d6e23c|5488c096e4b02acb4f0c92da.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdate|unknown

52824fe6e4b08f1425d6e23c|5488c10ee4b02acb4f0c93a4.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/lworkcit/citeinfo/pubinfo/pubplace|Reston, Virginia
52824fe6e4b08f1425d6e23c|5488c10ee4b02acb4f0c93a4.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/lworkcit/citeinfo/pubinfo/publish|U.S. Geological Survey
52824fe6e4b08f1425d6e23c|5488c10ee4b02acb4f0c93a4.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/lworkcit/citeinfo/onlink|http://pubs.usgs.gov/sir/2014/5151/
52824fe6e4b08f1425d6e23c|5488c10ee4b02acb4f0c93a4.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/abstract|Water levels in 93 wells completed in the Wood River Valley aquifer system were measured during October 2224, 2012; these wells are part of a network established by the U.S. Geological Survey in 2006. Maps of the October 2012 water-table altitude in the unconfined aquifer and the potentiometric-surface altitude of the confined aquifer have similar topology to those on maps of October 2006 conditions. Between October 2006 and October 2012, water-table altitude in the unconfined aquifer rose by as much as 1.86 feet in 6 wells and declined by as much as 14.28 feet in 77 wells; average decline was 2.9 feet. From October 2006 to October 2012, the potentiometric-surface altitude in 10 wells completed in the confined aquifer declined between 0.12 and 20.50 feet; average decline was 6.8 feet.
52824fe6e4b08f1425d6e23c|5488c10ee4b02acb4f0c93a4.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/purpose|This dataset documents October 2012 ground-water conditions for the confined aquifer in the Wood River Valley, and in comparison with October 2006 ground-water data, to estimate changes in water levels between the two periods.

52824fe6e4b08f1425d6e23c|5488c10fe4b02acb4f0c93ac.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/lworkcit/citeinfo/title|Water-Level Changes and Change in Water in Storage in the High Plains Aquifer, Predevelopment to 2013 and 2011-13
52824fe6e4b08f1425d6e23c|5488c10fe4b02acb4f0c93ac.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/lworkcit/citeinfo/geoform|document
52824fe6e4b08f1425d6e23c|5488c10fe4b02acb4f0c93ac.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/lworkcit/citeinfo/serinfo/sername|U.S. Geological Survey Scientific Investigations Report
52824fe6e4b08f1425d6e23c|5488c10fe4b02acb4f0c93ac.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/lworkcit/citeinfo/serinfo/issue|2014-5218
52824fe6e4b08f1425d6e23c|5488c10fe4b02acb4f0c93ac.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/lworkcit/citeinfo/pubinfo/pubplace|Reston, VA
52824fe6e4b08f1425d6e23c|5488c10fe4b02acb4f0c93ac.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/lworkcit/citeinfo/pubinfo/publish|U.S. Geological Survey
52824fe6e4b08f1425d6e23c|5488c10fe4b02acb4f0c93ac.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/lworkcit/citeinfo/onlink|http://dx.doi.org/10.3133/sir20145218/
52824fe6e4b08f1425d6e23c|5488c10fe4b02acb4f0c93ac.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/abstract|The High Plains aquifer extends from south of 32 degrees to almost 44 degrees north latitude and from 96 degrees 30 minutes to 104 degrees west longitude. The aquifer underlies about 175,000 square miles in parts of Colorado, Kansas, Nebraska, New Mexico, Oklahoma, South Dakota, Texas, and Wyoming. This dataset consists of a raster of water-level changes for the High Plains aquifer, predevelopment (about 1950) to 2013. This digital dataset was created using water-level measurements from 3,349 wells measured in both the predevelopment period (about 1950) and in 2013 and using other published information on water-level change in areas with few water-level measurements. The map was reviewed for consistency with the relevant data at a scale of 1:1,000,000.
52824fe6e4b08f1425d6e23c|5488c10fe4b02acb4f0c93ac.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/purpose|This dataset was created to document water-level changes in the High Plains aquifer from predevelopment (about 1950) to 2013.
52824fe6e4b08f1425d6e23c|5488c10fe4b02acb4f0c93ac.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/supplinf|This raster dataset is associated with the U.S. Geological Survey Scientific Investigations Report (SIR 2014-5218, McGuire, 2014), which describes the methods used to generate this raster dataset.

52824fe6e4b08f1425d6e23c|5488c10fe4b02acb4f0c93ac.xml|/metadata/idinfo/datacred|The water-level data used to map water-level changes was provided by the following Federal, State, and local entities: Colorado--Division of Water Resources (also known as the Office of the State Engineer); Kansas--Department of Agriculture, Division of Water Resources and the Kansas Geological Survey; Nebraska--Central Nebraska Public Power and Irrigation District, Natural Resources Districts, and University of Nebraska-Lincoln, Conservation and Survey Division; New Mexico--Office of the State Engineer; Oklahoma--Water Resources Board; South Dakota--Department of Environment and Natural Resources; Texas--Groundwater Conservation Districts and the Water Development Board; Wyoming--State Engineers Office; and Federal--Bureau of Reclamation, U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, and U.S. Geological Survey.
52824fe6e4b08f1425d6e23c|5488c10fe4b02acb4f0c93ac.xml|/metadata/idinfo/native|Microsoft Windows 7 Version 6.1 (Build 7601) Service Pack 1; Esri ArcGIS 10.1.1.3143
52824fe6e4b08f1425d6e23c|5488c10fe4b02acb4f0c93ac.xml|/metadata/dataqual/attracc/attraccr|The water-level-change data used as the basis for this dataset were computed primarily from water levels measured in wells during both the predevelopment period and in 2013 and from other published data.
52824fe6e4b08f1425d6e23c|5488c10fe4b02acb4f0c93ac.xml|/metadata/dataqual/attracc/qattracc/attraccv|variable
52824fe6e4b08f1425d6e23c|5488c10fe4b02acb4f0c93ac.xml|/metadata/dataqual/attracc/qattracc/attracce|The precision of the water-level measurements is estimated to be 0.01 feet (ft), if there is not oil in the well. The accuracy of the water-level measurements can be affected by many factors; if there is oil on the surface of the water, the error in the water-level measurement could be as much as 5 ft, depending on the depth of the oil. The accuracy of the water-level change value for a given cell is dependent on the proximity of cell to measured wells. The average, median, and maximum distance between wells, which were measured in predevelopment and in 2013, is 3.2 miles, 2.7 miles, and 20.1 miles, respectively. In the area of water-level changes from a decline of 5 ft to a rise of 5 ft, the cell's water-level change value was set to zero because of uncertainty in the interpolation of water-level changes less than 5 ft, especially in areas with few measured wells.
52824fe6e4b08f1425d6e23c|5488c10fe4b02acb4f0c93ac.xml|/metadata/dataqual/logic|Not applicable for raster data.
52824fe6e4b08f1425d6e23c|5488c10fe4b02acb4f0c93ac.xml|/metadata/dataqual/complete|Dataset is complete for the High Plains area. Data gaps within the High Plains boundary indicate areas where the aquifer is not present.
52824fe6e4b08f1425d6e23c|5488c10fe4b02acb4f0c93ac.xml|/metadata/dataqual/posacc/horizpa/horizpar|The accuracy of the water-level change value for a given cell is dependent on the proximity of cell to measured wells. The average, median, and maximum distance between wells, which were measured in predevelopment and in 2013, is 3.2 miles, 2.7 miles, and 20.1 miles, respectively. The interpolation process uses the water-level change value from measured wells and other supporting data. For cells collocated with measured well(s), the interpolation process results in cell values that are generally similar to, but commonly not equal to, the calculated values for the measured well(s).

52824fe6e4b08f1425d6e23c|5488c10fe4b02acb4f0c93ac.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/srcinfo/srccontr|Water-level data with the well's land-surface altitude and spatial location.
52824fe6e4b08f1425d6e23c|5488c10fe4b02acb4f0c93ac.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|The following data and datasets were assembled: (1) static depth-to-water data from wells completed in the High Plains aquifer and measured after the 2012 irrigation season and before the 2013 irrigation season (Kansas Geological Survey, 2014; Texas Water Development Board, 2014; U.S. Geological Survey, 2014); (2) static depth-to-water data from wells, which are located in New Mexico, completed in the High Plains aquifer, and measured after the previous year's irrigation season and before the specified year's irrigation season for 2009 to 2012 (U.S. Geological Survey, 2014); (3) static depth-to-water data from wells, which are located in Wyoming, completed in the High Plains aquifer, and measured after the 2011 irrigation season and before the 2012 irrigation season (U.S. Geological Survey, 2014); (4) the aquifer boundary and the boundary of internal areas where the aquifer is not present (Qi, 2010); (5) areas in the High Plains aquifer with little or no saturated thickness (Gutentag and others, 1984; Cederstrand and Becker, 1999a); (6) the location and extent of major faults within the High Plains aquifer (Cederstrand and Becker, 1999b); (7) water-level change contours, predevelopment to 2011, High Plains aquifer (McGuire, 2013); (8) predevelopment and 1980 water levels for wells completed in the High Plains aquifer (Luckey and others, 1981; Gutentag and others, 1984); and (9) published water-level change contours in areas with few predevelopment water levels in Wyoming and Nebraska (Lowry, 1967; Luckey and others, 1981; University of Nebraska-Lincoln, Conservation and Survey Division, 2013).

52824fe6e4b08f1425d6e23c|5488c10fe4b02acb4f0c93ac.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|The raster output from the initial run of Esri Arc/Info Version 10.0 TOPOGRID was contoured using the Esri Arc/Info Version 10.0 CONTOUR command. The contour intervals were less than -150 ft, -150 to -100 ft, -100 to -50 ft, -50 to -25 ft, -25 to -10 ft, -10 to -5 ft, -5 to +5 ft, 5 to 10 ft, 10 to 25 ft, and greater than 50 ft.
52824fe6e4b08f1425d6e23c|5488c10fe4b02acb4f0c93ac.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdate|2014
52824fe6e4b08f1425d6e23c|5488c10fe4b02acb4f0c93ac.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|A map of the contours of water-level change, predevelopment to 2013, was prepared with the primary and supplemental point datasets presented for a manual review and revision of the contours particularly in areas where few wells had the applicable water-level measurements. The modified contours were converted to polygons, using the Esri Arc/Info Version 10.0 BUILD command, each polygon was populated with the contour range, and the polygons were converted into two rasters using the Esri Arc/Info Version 10.0 POLYGRID command. One raster, r1_pd13max, was populated with the lowest (for polygons of declines) or highest (for polygons of rises) value of the polygon range, that is, -149.99 for the polygon of declines less than or equal to -100 ft and greater than -150 ft, and 49.99 for the polygons of rises greater than or equal to 25 ft and less than 50 ft. The second raster, r2_pd13min, was populated with the highest (for polygons of declines) or lowest (for polygons of rises) value of the polygon range, that is -100.01 for the polygon of declines less than or equal to -100 ft and greater than -150 ft, and 25.01 ft for the polygons of rises greater than or equal to 25 ft and less than 50 ft.
52824fe6e4b08f1425d6e23c|5488c10fe4b02acb4f0c93ac.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdate|2014
52824fe6e4b08f1425d6e23c|5488c10fe4b02acb4f0c93ac.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|The Esri Arc/Info Version 10.0 command POLYGRID was used to create a raster of the areas of water-level changes between a rise of 5 ft and a decline of 5 ft. The value of the raster, titled h_nscpd13_g, is 1 in these areas and 0 elsewhere.
52824fe6e4b08f1425d6e23c|5488c10fe4b02acb4f0c93ac.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/srcused|None
52824fe6e4b08f1425d6e23c|5488c10fe4b02acb4f0c93ac.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdate|2014
52824fe6e4b08f1425d6e23c|5488c10fe4b02acb4f0c93ac.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|The Esri Arc/Info Version 10.0 TOPOGRID command was used to generate a revised raster of water-level change from predevelopment to 2013 using as inputs the calculated value deltapd_13 for each well measured in predevelopment and 2013 (Kansas Geological Survey, 2014; Texas Water Development Board, 2014; U.S. Geological Survey, 2014), the aquifer boundary (Qi, 2010), and, to guide water-level contours in areas with few wells, the manually modified contours of water-level change, predevelopment to 2013. TOPOGRID was run with (1) the boundary equal to the aquifer outer boundary; (2) the point file of the aquifer boundary, aq_only_pt, using attribute field beginval; (3) the point file hp_pd13pts, attribute field deltapd_13; (4) the contour file v2WLCPD13b, attribute field tgcontour; (5) drainage enforcement off; (6) tolerances set to 0 for accuracy and density of the elevation points, 1 for horizontal standard error, and 0 for vertical standard error; and (7) 30 iterations. The output TOPOGRID raster was titled h_ga01a_pd13.
52824fe6e4b08f1425d6e23c|5488c10fe4b02acb4f0c93ac.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/srcused|Kansas Geological Survey, 2014
52824fe6e4b08f1425d6e23c|5488c10fe4b02acb4f0c93ac.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/srcused|Qi, 2010
52824fe6e4b08f1425d6e23c|5488c10fe4b02acb4f0c93ac.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/srcused|Texas Water Development Board, 2014
52824fe6e4b08f1425d6e23c|5488c10fe4b02acb4f0c93ac.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/srcused|U.S. Geological Survey, 2014
52824fe6e4b08f1425d6e23c|5488c10fe4b02acb4f0c93ac.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/srcused|University of Nebraska-Lincoln, Conservation and Survey Division, 2013
52824fe6e4b08f1425d6e23c|5488c10fe4b02acb4f0c93ac.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdate|2014
52824fe6e4b08f1425d6e23c|5488c10fe4b02acb4f0c93ac.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|The revised raster of water-level change from predevelopment to 2013 was modified further using the Esri Arc/Info Version 10.0 commands SETNULL and CON with applicable rasters to identify the cells to be changed. The SETNULL and CON commands were applied using the following rasters (1) raster g02_aqisle to change the cell values to missing data in areas where the aquifer is not present (Gutentag and others, 1984; Qi, 2010); (2) rasters r1_pd13max and r2_pd13min to examine the absolute value of each cell within the polygons of water-level change to reassign the cell's value, if appropriate, to either the lower value of the corresponding range (as absolute values) for the polygon, if the cell value was less than the polygons lower value, or to the higher value of the corresponding range (as absolute values) for the polygon, if the cell value was greater than the polygons higher value; (3) raster h_ldpd13_g to change the cell values to 10.01 in the areas of rises in Central Platte River Valley in Nebraska(Luckey and others, 1981; Gutentag and others, 1984); (4) raster h_nscpd13_g to change the cell values to zero in the areas with water-level change between a decline of 5 ft and a rise of 5 ft, because of uncertainty in interpolating relatively small water-level changes especially in areas where there are few wells measured in both predevelopment and 2013; and (5) raster gnosatpoly09 to change the cell values to missing data in the areas of little or no saturated thickness (Gutentag and others, 1984; Cederstrand and Becker, 1999a). The resultant raster with areas of no substantial change set to zero was titled h_ga01d_pd13. The resultant raster with areas of little or no saturated thickness set to null was titled h_ga01e_pd13.
52824fe6e4b08f1425d6e23c|5488c10fe4b02acb4f0c93ac.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/srcused|Qi, 2010
52824fe6e4b08f1425d6e23c|5488c10fe4b02acb4f0c93ac.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/srcused|Luckey and others, 1981
52824fe6e4b08f1425d6e23c|5488c10fe4b02acb4f0c93ac.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/srcused|Gutentag and others, 1984
52824fe6e4b08f1425d6e23c|5488c10fe4b02acb4f0c93ac.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/srcused|Cederstrand and Becker, 1999a
52824fe6e4b08f1425d6e23c|5488c10fe4b02acb4f0c93ac.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdate|2014
52824fe6e4b08f1425d6e23c|5488c10fe4b02acb4f0c93ac.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|The Esri Arc/Info Version 10.0 command ZONALMEAN was applied to the final raster of water-level changes to calculate the water-level change statistics for the entire aquifer and for each State, in ft.
52824fe6e4b08f1425d6e23c|5488c10fe4b02acb4f0c93ac.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/srcused|U.S. Geological Survey, 2005

52824fe6e4b08f1425d6e23c|5488c10fe4b02acb4f0c93ac.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|The raster with areas of no substantial change set to zero, which was titled h_ga01d_pd13, was renamed hp_wlcpd13g.
52824fe6e4b08f1425d6e23c|5488c10fe4b02acb4f0c93ac.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/srcused|None

52824fe6e4b08f1425d6e23c|5488c10fe4b02acb4f0c93ac.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdef|Water-level changes, in ft, predevelopment (about 1950) to 2013
52824fe6e4b08f1425d6e23c|5488c10fe4b02acb4f0c93ac.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdefs|USGS
52824fe6e4b08f1425d6e23c|5488c10fe4b02acb4f0c93ac.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommin|-199.89
52824fe6e4b08f1425d6e23c|5488c10fe4b02acb4f0c93ac.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommax|82.53
52824fe6e4b08f1425d6e23c|5488c10fe4b02acb4f0c93ac.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/attrunit|ft
52824fe6e4b08f1425d6e23c|5488c10fe4b02acb4f0c93ac.xml|/metadata/eainfo/overview/eaover|This floating-point raster dataset represent water-level change in the High Plains aquifer from predevelopment to 2013, in ft. The maximum and minimum value of the raster is -255.96 ft to 82.53 ft. The measured values for water-level changes, predevelopment to 2013, ranged from a decline of 256 ft for a well in Texas to a rise of 85 ft for a well in Nebraska. The interpolation process used to generate the rasters referred to in this report results in cell values, for cells collocated with a measured well, that are generally similar to, but commonly not exactly equal to, the corresponding values based on those water-level measurements. The cell values represent the value for an area 500 meters by 500 meters and the measured values are point values within the area represented by the cell.
52824fe6e4b08f1425d6e23c|5488c10fe4b02acb4f0c93ac.xml|/metadata/eainfo/overview/eadetcit|This raster dataset is shown in figure 1 in the report (SIR 2014-5218, McGuire, 2014) titled "Water-Level Changes and Change in Water in Storage in the High Plains Aquifer, Predevelopment to 2013 and 2011-13."
